intro: Opuntia engelmannii var. lindheimeri, commonly known as the Lindheimer’s prickly pear, is a species of cactus native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its flat, fleshy stems that are covered in spines and glochids, which serve as a defense mechanism against herbivores. The plant produces yellow to orange flowers during the spring and summer months, followed by red, fleshy fruits that are edible. Its leaves are reduced to spines, and the stems are photosynthetic, allowing it to thrive in arid environments. This variety is often found in rocky soils and is well-adapted to drought conditions.
